description: Located at the intersection of Independence Avenue and Zakharau Street, Victory Square is one of Belarus's most recognizable symbols. Centered around a 38-meter granite obelisk erected in 1954, it honors those who liberated Belarus from Nazi occupation and features an eternal flame at the Grave of the Unknown Soldier.
highlights: 38-meter granite obelisk with replica of Order of Victory crown
Sacred Sword of Victory at monument base
Four bronze reliefs depicting war scenes and glory
Memorial Hall underground with 566 Heroes of Soviet Union names
Four bronze wreaths representing liberation Fronts
Hourly changing of the guard ceremony
Capsules with soil from Soviet hero cities including Moscow, Leningrad, Stalingrad
tips: Visit during hourly changing of the guard for ceremonial display
Explore the Memorial Hall underground museum
Popular spot for Victory Day celebrations on May 9
Newlyweds often lay flowers here - a local tradition
Accessible via Victory Square metro station
Gorky Park and Svisloch embankment within walking distance
vibe: Reverent, ceremonial, deeply patriotic - a sacred space where national memory and personal grief intersect in perpetual remembrance
